lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about animals (squirrels and elephants) and find key details about people’s likes and what they do with animals.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the text aloud. Stop after each sentence and ask: “Who likes squirrels?” “What animal is in the park?” Students underline it.
stretchStrategies: Secret Word Builders: Write the letters r, g, l, o on the board. Students work in pairs to create and write as many real animal-related or nature-related words as possible using those letters (e.g. log, frog, gorilla). For stretch, ask them to use one word in a sentence.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the letters r, g, l, o to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Write r, g, l, o on the board. Say: “/r/ – rabbit.” Students repeat and write the letter in notebooks.
stretchStrategies: Secret Word Builders: Write the letters r, g, l, o on the board. Students work in pairs to create and write as many real animal-related or nature-related words as possible using those letters (e.g. log, frog, gorilla). For stretch, ask them to use one word in a sentence.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say one fact about squirrels in Canada and one fact about elephants in India.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Point to the map/photo of Canada or India. Ask: “What animals live here?” Use the SB to support responses.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

Phonics introduces each vowel with one sound, which quickly breaks down past the Kindergarten 2 level. Think of the es in elephant or the as in banana. This does not happen in Vietnamese, where every vowel is pronounced as written.
Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
